articles.headline: Obama Tactic Shields Health Care Bill From a Filibuster
articles.snippet: The president’s new stance suggests he may be much less willing to compromise on health care, his top legislative priority, even if it means a partisan fight.
articles.abstract: The president’s new stance suggests he may be much less willing to compromise on health care, his top legislative priority, even if it means a partisan fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  At the prodding of the White House, Democratic Congressional leaders have agreed to pursue a plan that would protect major health care legislation from Republican opposition by shielding it from last-minute Senate filibusters.

articles.headline: The Pros and Cons of Buying a Chrysler or G.M.
articles.snippet: With automakers facing bankruptcy, car shoppers would do well to think beyond the sticker price.
articles.abstract: With automakers facing bankruptcy, car shoppers would do well to think beyond the sticker price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should you buy a Chrysler or General Motors vehicle right now?

articles.headline: New Worries for Next Tier of Banks
articles.snippet: Absent new details on how the largest banks fared in a government test of their health, analysts are turning the spotlight on a handful of regional banks that they think may be the next weak links.
articles.abstract: Absent new details on how the largest banks fared in a government test of their health, analysts are turning the spotlight on a handful of regional banks that they think may be the next weak links.
articles.lead_paragraph: Absent fresh details on how the nation’s 19 largest banks fared in a new government test of their health, analysts are turning the spotlight on a handful of major regional banks that they reckon may be the next weak links in the financial industry.

articles.headline: Auctions for Troubled Property Loans Jump to the Web
articles.snippet: Investor interest in buying distressed assets is surging, and eBay-like auction sites are growing rapidly, with still bigger growth forecast.
articles.abstract: Investor interest in buying distressed assets is surging, and eBay-like auction sites are growing rapidly, with still bigger growth forecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not a game for novices or for anyone lacking courage. But for investors with the right expertise and a serious appetite for risk, the credit crisis is shaping up as a once-in-a-lifetime chance to buy troubled real estate assets on the cheap.

articles.headline: Indonesia’s Voters Retreat From Radical Islam
articles.snippet: People in the world’s most populous Muslim nation are punishing narrowly religious parties at the polls, going against a trend in other Islamic countries.
articles.abstract: People in the world’s most populous Muslim nation are punishing narrowly religious parties at the polls, going against a trend in other Islamic countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia  From Pakistan to Gaza and Lebanon, militant Islamic movements have gained ground rapidly in recent years, fanning Western fears of a consolidation of radical Muslim governments. But here in the world’s most populous Muslim nation just the opposite is happening, with Islamic parties suffering a steep drop in popular support.

articles.headline: As Jobs Die, Europe’s Migrants Head Home
articles.snippet: After a decade of growth that attracted workers to booming Western countries, a reversal is taking place.
articles.abstract: After a decade of growth that attracted workers to booming Western countries, a reversal is taking place.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALCALÁ de HENARES, Spain  Six years after the Spanish construction boom lured him here from his native Romania, Constantin Marius Mituletu is going home, another victim of the bust that is reversing the human tide that has transformed Europe in the past decade.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Suit Claims JPMorgan Aided Madoff’s Fraud
articles.snippet: Victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme accused JPMorgan Chase of aiding his crime by maintaining his checking accounts and trading with him after the bank realized he was running a fraud.
articles.abstract: Victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme accused JPMorgan Chase of aiding his crime by maintaining his checking accounts and trading with him after the bank realized he was running a fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme have accused his banker, JPMorgan Chase, of aiding his crime by maintaining his checking accounts and trading with his brokerage firm long after the bank itself realized that its prized customer was running a vast fraud.

articles.headline: Obama Takes 100th-Day Hoopla and Runs With It
articles.snippet: Aides who once professed disdain for a numerical moment are now working to turn it to the president’s advantage.
articles.abstract: Aides who once professed disdain for a numerical moment are now working to turn it to the president’s advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When it comes to the whole 100 Days hoopla, President Obama and his team were against it before they were for it.

articles.headline: Iraq Resists Pleas by U.S. to Placate Baath Party
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has refused to reconcile with officials of Saddam Hussein’s party, which he blames for some recent bombings.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has refused to reconcile with officials of Saddam Hussein’s party, which he blames for some recent bombings.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  On April 18, American and British officials from a secretive unit called the Force Strategic Engagement Cell flew to Jordan to try to persuade one of Saddam Hussein’s top generals  the commander of the final defense of Baghdad in 2003  to return home to resume efforts to make peace with the new Iraq.

articles.headline: House Heavyweight Feels Threat to Power
articles.snippet: A string of federal criminal investigations of contractors or lobbyists close to Representative John P. Murtha are threatening to undermine his legendary backroom clout.
articles.abstract: A string of federal criminal investigations of contractors or lobbyists close to Representative John P. Murtha are threatening to undermine his legendary backroom clout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  So powerful was Representative John P. Murtha at one time that he used to put up billboards in his Western Pennsylvania district declaring that “the P is for Power.” Few in Congress dared disagree: he doled out or withheld billions in federal money each year for lawmakers’ pet projects, better known as earmarks.

articles.headline: Does H.P. Need a Dose of Anarchy?
articles.snippet: Mark V. Hurd took over Hewlett-Packard and made it the world’s largest technology company. The giant is now finding its way in a world full of smaller, more agile rivals.
articles.abstract: Mark V. Hurd took over Hewlett-Packard and made it the world’s largest technology company. The giant is now finding its way in a world full of smaller, more agile rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Palo Alto, Calif.

articles.headline: A Reality Check on Mortgage Modification
articles.snippet: A mortgage modification bill in Congress would create problems like conflicts of interests and the elimination of certain liabilities.
articles.abstract: A mortgage modification bill in Congress would create problems like conflicts of interests and the elimination of certain liabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WE are almost two years into the housing storm and foreclosure floodwaters continue to rise. A record 800,000 homes received a default or auction notice in the first quarter, an increase of 9 percent from the fourth quarter of 2008, according to RealtyTrac. And one in five mortgage loans exceeded the value of the underlying property at the end of 2008, according to data from American CoreLogic Inc.

articles.headline: Would Detroit Sound Any Better in Italian?
articles.snippet: Fiat executives believe they can profit from Detroit’s failings, but the Italian automaker was itself near bankruptcy recently.
articles.abstract: Fiat executives believe they can profit from Detroit’s failings, but the Italian automaker was itself near bankruptcy recently.
articles.lead_paragraph: Turin, Italy

articles.headline: After Off Year, Wall Street Pay Is Bouncing Back
articles.snippet: If the pace set in the first quarter continues all year, the average pay for bankers — much of it in bonuses — will rebound from the lows of last year.
articles.abstract: If the pace set in the first quarter continues all year, the average pay for bankers — much of it in bonuses — will rebound from the lows of last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rest of the nation may be getting back to basics, but on Wall Street, paychecks still come with a golden promise.

articles.headline: In Pakistan, Guile Helps Taliban Gain
articles.snippet: The fall of Buner, a strategic district in Pakistan, involved tactics that could be replicated elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The fall of Buner, a strategic district in Pakistan, involved tactics that could be replicated elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Initially, Buner was a hard place for the Taliban to crack. When they attacked a police station in the valley district last year, the resistance was fearless. Local people picked up rifles, pistols and daggers, hunted down the militants and killed six of them.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Students Fall Ill in New York, and Swine Flu Is Likely Cause
articles.snippet: The eight suspected cases were said to be mild, and there have been no deaths from swine flu in the U.S., but the outbreak has killed at least 81 people in Mexico.
articles.abstract: The eight suspected cases were said to be mild, and there have been no deaths from swine flu in the U.S., but the outbreak has killed at least 81 people in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tests show that eight students at a Queens high school are likely to have contracted the human swine flu virus that has struck Mexico and a small number of other people in the United States, health officials in New York City said yesterday.

articles.headline: U.S. Declares Public Health Emergency Over Swine Flu
articles.snippet: U.S. health officials said that they had confirmed 20 cases of swine flu in the country and expected to see more as investigators track the path of the outbreak.
articles.abstract: U.S. health officials said that they had confirmed 20 cases of swine flu in the country and expected to see more as investigators track the path of the outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: Responding to what some health officials feared could be the leading edge of a global pandemic emerging from Mexico, American health officials declared a public health emergency on Sunday as 20 cases of swine flu were confirmed in this country, including eight in New York City.

articles.headline: Empire of Martha Marches On
articles.snippet: Martha Stewart is prevented from serving as a corporate officer at the company she founded until 2011. But she is still very much the creative maypole of the franchise.
articles.abstract: Martha Stewart is prevented from serving as a corporate officer at the company she founded until 2011. But she is still very much the creative maypole of the franchise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martha Stewart is prevented by law from running her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia. But you get the feeling that no one else is allowed to run it without her say-so, either.

articles.headline: More Atheists Shout It From the Rooftops
articles.snippet: Organized atheist groups liken their strategy to the gay-rights movement, which lifted off when members of a scorned minority went public.
articles.abstract: Organized atheist groups liken their strategy to the gay-rights movement, which lifted off when members of a scorned minority went public.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Two months after the local atheist organization here put up a billboard saying “Don’t Believe in God? You Are Not Alone,” the group’s 13 board members met in Laura and Alex Kasman’s living room to grapple with the fallout.

articles.headline: Chrysler and Union Agree to Deal Before Federal Deadline
articles.snippet: Even with the agreement, which includes Fiat, Chrysler is expected to seek Chapter 11 protection, in a case mapped out by the government in advance.
articles.abstract: Even with the agreement, which includes Fiat, Chrysler is expected to seek Chapter 11 protection, in a case mapped out by the government in advance.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Union leaders said Sunday that they had reached an agreement with Chrysler that meets federal requirements for the automaker to receive more financing.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Losses in Good-Will Values Compound Bank Troubles
articles.snippet: Write-downs for good-will losses have already been in the tens of billions of dollars, and analysts say they are likely to continue as companies reassess the value of old deals.
articles.abstract: Write-downs for good-will losses have already been in the tens of billions of dollars, and analysts say they are likely to continue as companies reassess the value of old deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: When times were flush, businesses bought up rivals and absorbed smaller companies to grow as big as possible as fast as possible. But now, those purchases are starting to look a lot like housing bought at the peak of the bubble  overpriced and losing value fast.

articles.headline: As Economic Turmoil Mounts, So Do Attacks on Hungary’s Gypsies
articles.snippet: Over the past year, at least seven Roma — long among Europe’s most oppressed minority groups — have been killed in Hungary.
articles.abstract: Over the past year, at least seven Roma — long among Europe’s most oppressed minority groups — have been killed in Hungary.
articles.lead_paragraph: TISZALOK, Hungary  Jeno Koka was a doting grandfather and dedicated worker on his way to his night-shift job at a chemical plant last week when he was shot dead at his doorstep. To his killer, he was just a Gypsy, and that seems to have been reason enough.

articles.headline: With Rivals Ahead, Doubts for CNN’s Middle Road
articles.snippet: CNN has struggled to effectively compete against its rivals stoking prime time with high-octane political opinion and rant.
articles.abstract: CNN has struggled to effectively compete against its rivals stoking prime time with high-octane political opinion and rant.
articles.lead_paragraph: The election of Barack Obama does not seem to have ushered in a kinder, less-polarized environment in politics  or television.

articles.headline: In Developing Countries, Web Grows Without Profit
articles.snippet: To serve emerging markets, companies like YouTube need to invest in expensive servers, but ad revenue for those countries doesn’t cover those additional costs.
articles.abstract: To serve emerging markets, companies like YouTube need to invest in expensive servers, but ad revenue for those countries doesn’t cover those additional costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook is booming in Turkey and Indonesia. YouTube’s audience has nearly doubled in India and Brazil.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Geithner, Member and Overseer of Finance Club
articles.snippet: As head of the New York Fed, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner built close relationships on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: As head of the New York Fed, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner built close relationships on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last June, with a financial hurricane gathering force, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. convened the nation’s economic stewards for a brainstorming session. What emergency powers might the government want at its disposal to confront the crisis? he asked.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: An Indiana Town Appreciates Obama, and That Stimulus Cash, Too
articles.snippet: In Anderson, Ind., a swing town in a swing state, the hopes raised by President Obama’s fast start carry the risks of promises unkept.
articles.abstract: In Anderson, Ind., a swing town in a swing state, the hopes raised by President Obama’s fast start carry the risks of promises unkept.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDERSON, Ind.  At the city parks office, Pam Clendenen thumbed through a three-inch-thick printout of President Obama’s economic stimulus plan to see if the money could be used to replace dilapidated playground equipment.

articles.headline: G.M.'s Latest Plan Envisions a Much Smaller Automaker
articles.snippet: G.M. expects to pare its American work force to 38,000 union employees, compared with 395,000 at its peak in 1970.
articles.abstract: G.M. expects to pare its American work force to 38,000 union employees, compared with 395,000 at its peak in 1970.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  For all the uncertainty swirling around General Motors, the troubled automaker said Monday that one thing was clear: it must become drastically smaller if it hopes to remain a viable company, regardless of whether it has to file for bankruptcy.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley
